writing_prompt: While searching through your partner's bag for a pen, you stumble upon a wooden stake and an old prom photo, uncovering a past filled with vampire slaying, werewolf boyfriends, and secrets you never expected.
story:
Luna Lovegood was rummaging through her girlfriend's bag, a colorful patchwork of leather and fabric that seemed to hold endless mysteries. She needed a pen, but as she dug deeper, her fingers brushed against something smooth and wooden. Curious, she pulled it out, revealing a finely crafted wooden stake. 

"That's peculiar," she murmured to herself, her eyes widening with intrigue. Just beneath the stake, something else caught her eye—a slightly crumpled, old prom photo.

Luna sat down on the edge of the couch, examining the picture closely. There was Ginny, her fiery red hair unmistakable, wearing a stunning dress and standing next to a tall, brooding figure with dark eyes and a leather jacket. A werewolf, Luna realized with a start, recognizing the telltale signs from her extensive reading on magical creatures.

Luna's heart raced as she pieced together the implications. Ginny had always been a bit elusive about her past, but Luna had never pressed, respecting her privacy. Now, it seemed, she had stumbled upon a secret life filled with more danger and adventure than she could have ever imagined.

The front door creaked open, and Ginny stepped in, her eyes lighting up at the sight of Luna. "Hey, love, what are you doing?"

Luna looked up, the stake and photo still in her hands. "I was looking for a pen," she said softly, "but I found these instead."

Ginny's face paled slightly, and she closed the door behind her. "I see you found my old slaying kit," she said with a nervous laugh. "I suppose I should have told you about my past sooner."

Luna's eyes sparkled with curiosity. "You used to be a vampire slayer?"

Ginny nodded, coming over to sit beside her. "Yes, back in my sixth year at Hogwarts, I was chosen as a Slayer. It was... intense. I had to juggle school, Quidditch, and keeping the wizarding world safe from vampires and other dark creatures."

"And the werewolf?" Luna asked, pointing to the photo.

"That’s Oz," Ginny explained. "He was my prom date and, for a time, my boyfriend. He was a werewolf, but he had it under control. We had some wild times together."

Luna's mind whirled, trying to reconcile the image of her sweet, caring Ginny with this fierce warrior who had fought the forces of darkness. "Why didn't you tell me?"

Ginny sighed, taking Luna's hands in hers. "I didn't want to burden you with my past. I wanted to leave that life behind and start fresh with you. But I realize now that keeping secrets wasn't fair to you."

Luna squeezed Ginny's hands gently. "Your past is part of who you are, Ginny. I love you for all of it, even the parts I didn't know about."

Ginny's eyes filled with tears of relief. "Thank you, Luna. It means the world to me."

"So," Luna said with a mischievous smile, "tell me more about your adventures. I want to know everything."

Ginny laughed, her tension melting away. "Alright, but it's a long story. Let's make some tea and settle in."

As they moved to the kitchen, Luna felt a warm sense of excitement. Their relationship had just deepened, filled with new layers and shared stories. She couldn't wait to explore this new chapter with Ginny, embracing every part of her incredible past.

writing_prompt: When Hermione's partners, Ginny and Luna, propose an unconventional plan to start a family with the help of Harry and Draco, the group must navigate the complexities of love, friendship, and the magic of creating something new together.
story:
Ginny twirled a lock of her fiery red hair around her finger, her eyes alight with excitement. "Hermione, Luna and I have been thinking," she began, her tone a mixture of nerves and enthusiasm. "We want to start a family."

Hermione looked up from her book, a little taken aback. "A family? That's wonderful, but how do you propose we do that?" She glanced at Luna, who was smiling dreamily, her usual ethereal calmness enveloping the room.

Luna leaned forward, her eyes sparkling with the kind of mischief that only she could pull off while still looking serene. "We've been researching some very interesting magical methods," she said. "And we thought, why not involve Harry and Draco?"

Hermione's eyes widened. "Harry and Draco? As in, our Harry and Draco?"

Ginny nodded, her excitement palpable. "Yes, exactly. They’re both so dear to us, and they’ve been talking about starting a family too. We thought it could be... perfect."

Hermione closed her book, her mind racing with possibilities. "So, you mean a magical process where all four of us contribute?"

Luna clapped her hands softly. "Exactly. There’s a spell, an old one, that we found in one of my mother's journals. It’s designed to merge the magical and physical attributes of all parents involved."

Hermione couldn't help but smile at Luna's enthusiasm. "It sounds both complex and beautiful. Have you spoken to Harry and Draco about this?"

Ginny nodded. "We wanted to talk to you first, of course. But they’re coming over for dinner tonight. We thought we could bring it up then."

***

That evening, the dining room was filled with the aroma of a hearty meal and the soft glow of candlelight. Harry and Draco arrived, hand in hand, their smiles wide as they greeted their friends.

Over dinner, Hermione broached the subject. "Harry, Draco, we have something important to discuss with you."

Harry looked curious, while Draco raised an eyebrow in his characteristic way. "Go on," Draco said, his voice smooth and inquisitive.

Ginny took a deep breath. "We’ve been thinking about starting a family, and we wanted to know if you both would be interested in joining us in this journey."

Harry blinked, clearly surprised. "You mean, all of us? Together?"

Luna nodded, her smile gentle. "Yes. There’s a spell that can incorporate all of our magical essences. It would mean that our child would carry a part of each of us."

Draco’s expression softened, and he looked at Harry. "What do you think?"

Harry’s face broke into a warm smile. "I think it sounds... incredible. But it’s a big step. Are we ready for this?"

Hermione reached out to touch Harry’s hand. "We’ve always been a family, in one way or another. This would just make it more... official."

Draco's eyes sparkled with rare emotion. "I’ve always wanted to be a father," he admitted. "And with you all, it feels right."

The group spent the next few weeks preparing for the spell, gathering ingredients and studying the incantations. The night of the ritual, they gathered in the living room, which was transformed into a sanctuary of warmth and magic.

Hermione stood at the center, her wand raised. "Ready?" she asked, her voice steady.

They nodded, forming a circle around a glowing crystal at the center. The air was thick with anticipation and love.

"Coniunctio Magica," Hermione intoned, her wand moving in intricate patterns. The crystal began to glow brighter, and tendrils of light reached out to each of them, connecting them in a web of magic and emotion.

As the spell reached its climax, the light enveloped them completely, filling the room with a sense of unity and purpose. When the light faded, they were left standing, breathless but exhilarated.

Ginny's eyes were shining with tears of joy. "We did it," she whispered, her voice full of awe.

Luna squeezed her hand. "Yes, we did."

Harry and Draco embraced, their eyes meeting with a shared understanding of the journey ahead.

Hermione looked around at her partners and friends, feeling an overwhelming sense of love and hope. They had taken the first step on a new, magical journey together, and she knew that whatever challenges lay ahead, they would face them as a family.

writing_prompt: As Lionel boards the Hogwarts Express on his birthday, clutching his new black cat named Panther, he wonders what surprises await him at school—and which house will become his new home.
story:
Lionel stepped onto the Hogwarts Express, clutching Panther close to his chest. The sleek black cat purred, vibrating against his ribcage, a comforting thrum on this nerve-wracking day. The train's whistle echoed through the platform, a call to adventure that sent shivers down Lionel's spine. Today was his birthday, and he couldn't help but wonder what surprises awaited him at Hogwarts, and which house he would soon call home.

He navigated the crowded corridors, peering into compartments filled with chattering students. "Mind if I sit here?" he asked a group of first-years who nodded eagerly, their eyes widening at the sight of Panther.

"Blimey, that's a fine cat you've got there!" exclaimed a round-faced boy named Ted.

"Thanks," Lionel replied, settling into a seat. "His name is Panther."

Panther leapt from Lionel's arms and onto the seat beside him, curling into a tight ball. Lionel found himself chatting animatedly with Ted and another girl named Marigold, who had curly red hair and a warm smile.

The train lurched forward, and Lionel gazed out the window, watching the countryside blur past. He couldn't contain his excitement, his thoughts racing ahead to the castle on the horizon.

"Have you heard about the Sorting Ceremony?" Marigold asked, her eyes sparkling with curiosity.

"Yeah," Lionel said. "I can't wait to find out which house I'll be in."

"I hope I'm in Gryffindor," Ted said, puffing out his chest. "My mum was a Gryffindor."

Marigold nodded. "My sister's a Ravenclaw, so it would be nice to join her. What about you, Lionel?"

Lionel shrugged, scratching Panther behind the ears. "I don't really know. I just hope I make friends and have a good time."

Their conversation was interrupted by a flash of light outside the window. Lionel leaned closer, squinting to see what it was. A flock of enchanted birds flew alongside the train, their feathers glinting in a myriad of colors, casting a magical glow inside the compartment.

"Wow," Marigold breathed. "That's beautiful."

As the birds veered off, the trolley witch arrived, her cart laden with sweets. Lionel bought a Chocolate Frog and shared it with Ted and Marigold, the three of them laughing as the frog hopped away and Panther tried to catch it.

Hours passed, filled with laughter, stories, and newfound camaraderie. Lionel felt a warmth growing inside him, a sense of belonging he hadn't anticipated. Panther remained a comforting presence, occasionally batting at Lionel's robes or purring softly.

Finally, the train slowed, and Lionel's heart raced. They were here. The students disembarked, gathering in groups as they were led to the boats that would carry them across the lake to the castle. The sight of Hogwarts illuminated against the night sky took Lionel's breath away.

Once inside the Great Hall, Lionel's nerves returned. The Sorting Ceremony began, and one by one, students were called to the front, the Sorting Hat proclaiming their houses. When it was Lionel's turn, his legs felt like jelly as he approached the hat.

"Ah, Lionel," the hat murmured in his ear. "Interesting... very interesting. A thirst for knowledge, but also a brave heart. Where to put you?"

Lionel closed his eyes, Panther's purr echoing in his mind. He thought of Ted and Marigold, and the friendships he'd already begun to form.

"Better be... HUFFLEPUFF!" the hat declared.

The Hufflepuff table erupted in cheers, and Lionel felt a swell of pride as he joined them. Panther leapt onto his lap, purring contentedly.

As he sat among his new housemates, Lionel knew this was just the beginning. The adventures, the friendships, the magic – it all lay ahead. With Panther by his side, he was ready for whatever surprises Hogwarts had in store.

writing_prompt: Years after the war, Severus Snape stumbles upon an art exhibit dedicated entirely to him, only to discover Hermione Granger is the artist—and she has a shocking secret to share.
story:
Severus Snape’s eyes narrowed as he entered the grand hall of the art exhibit, the air heavy with the scent of oil paint and varnish. His curiosity had been piqued by the whispered rumors of an entire exhibit dedicated to him, an unsettling notion for a man who preferred the shadows. The walls were adorned with portraits, each capturing a facet of his complex life. Potions, duels, and moments of quiet reflection were immortalized in vivid strokes of color.

As he moved deeper into the exhibit, he noticed the artist’s name emblazoned on a plaque: Hermione Granger. His brows furrowed in confusion. Hermione, the insufferable know-it-all, had become an artist? He had not seen her in years, not since her graduation. The thought of her spending so much time contemplating his life was both perplexing and oddly flattering.

He paused before a particularly striking piece. It depicted him standing alone in the Shrieking Shack, the moment of his near demise captured with haunting accuracy. His breath hitched as he took in the level of detail—the anguish in his eyes, the blood staining his robes. It was as if she had been there, witnessing his final moments.

“Severus.”

He turned sharply at the sound of her voice. Hermione stood behind him, her expression a mix of apprehension and determination. She had grown into a confident woman, her curls tamed into a sophisticated updo, her eyes still as bright and inquisitive as ever.

“Miss Granger,” he greeted curtly, masking his surprise. “This is... unexpected.”

“I can imagine,” she replied, stepping closer. “I never thought I’d see you here.”

“Nor I, you,” he retorted. “Why this exhibit? Why me?”

Hermione took a deep breath, her gaze dropping to the floor. “Because you deserve to be remembered, Severus. Not as the villain, but as the hero you truly were.”

His eyes softened, just a fraction. “And you believe these paintings will achieve that?”

“I do,” she said firmly. “But there’s more. There’s something I need to tell you.”

He folded his arms, his curiosity piqued. “Go on.”

Hermione hesitated, then reached into her bag, pulling out a small, worn journal. “I found this in the ruins of Spinner’s End. It’s your mother’s.”

Severus’s eyes widened as he took the journal, his fingers trembling slightly. “My mother’s...”

“Yes,” Hermione confirmed. “She wrote about her life, her struggles, her love for you. But there’s something else—something you need to know.”

She opened the journal to a marked page and handed it to him. As he read, his face grew pale. “This can’t be...”

“It is,” Hermione said softly. “Eileen Prince was a brilliant witch, but she was also a Seer. She foresaw your role in the war, your sacrifices. She knew you would be misunderstood, but she also knew you would be honored one day.”

Severus closed the journal, his emotions in turmoil. “Why tell me this now?”

“Because you deserve to know the truth,” Hermione said, her voice filled with conviction. “You deserve to know that you were loved, that your sacrifices were seen and appreciated.”

For the first time in years, Severus Snape felt a warmth spread through his chest. He looked at Hermione, truly seeing her for the first time. “Thank you, Hermione.”

She smiled, a genuine, heartfelt smile. “You’re welcome, Severus.”

As they stood together in the exhibit, surrounded by the echoes of his past, Severus felt a sense of peace he had never known. And for the first time, he allowed himself to hope for a future.

writing_prompt: When Hermione Granger starts her first day at LCorp, a chance encounter with Kara Danvers over spilled drinks leads to an unexpected connection—and perhaps more than just a shared lunch schedule.
story:
Hermione stepped into the sleek, glass-walled lobby of LCorp, her sensible heels clicking lightly on the polished marble floor. She took a deep breath, adjusting her bag over her shoulder, and approached the reception desk, where a friendly-looking woman with short, blonde hair greeted her.

“Good morning! You must be Hermione Granger, our new consultant,” the receptionist said, her smile warm and welcoming.

“Yes, that’s right,” Hermione replied, returning the smile. “I’m excited to get started.”

“Great! If you’ll just sign in here, I’ll have someone escort you to your office.”

Hermione signed the visitor log and handed the pen back. A moment later, a tall, lanky man with glasses and a slightly rumpled suit appeared.

“Hi, I’m Winn Schott. I’ll show you around,” he said, extending a hand.

“Nice to meet you, Winn,” Hermione said, shaking his hand firmly.

As Winn led her through the bright, bustling corridors of LCorp, Hermione marveled at the advanced technology and innovative designs that filled the space. They passed open-concept workstations, holographic displays, and even a small lab with various futuristic gadgets. Hermione’s curiosity was piqued, and she couldn’t wait to dive into her work here.

“Here’s your office,” Winn said, stopping in front of a glass-walled room with a stunning view of the city. “And if you need anything, just let me know.”

“Thank you, Winn,” Hermione said, stepping into her new workspace. She set her bag down and took a moment to appreciate the view before heading to the break room for a much-needed cup of tea.

The break room was a cozy space with comfortable seating and a well-stocked kitchenette. As Hermione reached for a mug, she collided with someone coming from the opposite direction, sending a cascade of coffee and tea splashing onto the floor.

“Oh, I’m so sorry!” Hermione exclaimed, grabbing a handful of napkins to help clean up the mess.

“No, it’s my fault—I wasn’t paying attention,” the other woman said, her cheeks flushing with embarrassment. She was beautiful, with striking blue eyes and long, blonde hair pulled back into a ponytail. “I’m Kara Danvers, by the way.”

“Hermione Granger,” Hermione replied, smiling despite the mishap. “Nice to meet you, Kara.”

They both laughed as they continued to mop up the spilled drinks, and the awkwardness quickly melted away. Once the mess was cleaned up, they made fresh cups of coffee and tea and settled into a nearby table.

“So, what brings you to LCorp?” Kara asked, taking a sip of her coffee.

“I’ve been hired as a consultant for their new project on sustainable energy,” Hermione explained. “It’s a bit different from my usual work, but I’m excited for the challenge.”

“That sounds fascinating,” Kara said, her eyes lighting up with interest. “I work in the media department, but I’ve always been interested in environmental issues.”

As they chatted, Hermione found herself drawn to Kara’s genuine enthusiasm and kindness. They discovered a shared love of books, particularly mystery novels, and quickly bonded over their mutual interests.

By the end of their impromptu coffee break, they had exchanged numbers and made plans to have lunch together the next day. As Hermione returned to her office, she couldn’t help but feel a flutter of excitement at the prospect of getting to know Kara better.

Maybe this first day at LCorp was the start of something wonderful.
